Turku becomes noticeably quieter during this holiday, with many businesses closed. If staying in the city, head to the Turku Archipelago for traditional celebrations including folk dancing, bonfires, and music.

Late June hosts preparations for the upcoming July festivals. Tourism increases as international visitors arrive for the summer season. Many outdoor activities are available, including swimming at beaches along the Ruissalo Island coastline and day trips to the Turku Archipelago. The restaurant boats along the Aura River are in full swing, offering dining with scenic views.

The Turku Medieval Market is one of the city's most popular annual events, taking place at the Old Great Square (Vanha Suurtori). This four-day festival brings the Middle Ages to life with period costumes, crafts, food, music, and performances. It's a wonderful opportunity to experience Finland's oldest city in a historical context.

Ruisrock, one of Europe's oldest rock festivals, takes place annually on Ruissalo Island. This major music event draws thousands of visitors to see both international and Finnish artists perform across multiple stages in a beautiful natural setting.

July is the warmest month in Turku with temperatures averaging 16-22°C (61-72°F) but sometimes reaching 25°C (77°F). This is peak tourist season with visitors from around the world exploring the city's attractions. Down by the Laituri, Finland's largest city center festival, takes place along the Aura River with predominantly Finnish music acts. July is also the wettest month in Turku, with around 85-89mm of rainfall and about 12-13 rainy days. The Paavo Nurmi Marathon, named after the famous Finnish runner, also takes place in July. Many locals leave Turku for vacation at summer cottages, creating an interesting mix where the city is simultaneously at its busiest with tourists and emptiest of residents.

The first three weeks of August continue with warm summer conditions. The Turku Music Festival, a celebration of diverse music genres from classical to jazz, takes place during August. The sea temperature reaches its warmest point in August, around 12.8°C (55°F), making it the best month for swimming in the archipelago. August is one of the wettest months in Turku, with rainfall similar to July at around 80mm.

Late August brings slightly cooler temperatures but still excellent conditions for exploring the city. Tourism begins to decrease as European summer holidays end. Locals begin to return from summer vacations, bringing a more authentic feel back to the city. This is considered one of the best times to visit Turku, with good weather but slightly lower tourist numbers than peak July.

September brings autumn to Turku with pleasant temperatures around 9-14°C (48-57°F) and beautiful fall colors beginning to appear in parks and gardens. The Turku Day celebration typically takes place in September, with various events across the city celebrating its history and culture. Tourism decreases as European summer holidays end, making this an excellent time to visit with good weather and fewer crowds. Cultural life intensifies with new exhibitions and performances as the winter cultural season begins. This is widely considered one of the best months to visit Turku, with comfortable temperatures and the beginning of autumn colors in the surrounding forests.

October brings autumn colors to their peak in Turku, with parks and forests showing stunning red and gold foliage. Temperatures cool significantly with averages around 5-8°C (41-46°F). Daylight hours decrease noticeably, with about 8-10 hours of daylight by the end of the month. This is a good time for museum visits, with the Turku Art Museum, Aboa Vetus & Ars Nova, and Turku Castle particularly popular. Tourism continues to decrease, creating good opportunities for value accommodation and uncrowded attractions. Rainy days become more common, so indoor activities gain popularity.

November brings increasingly cold and dark conditions to Turku, with temperatures around 0-3°C (32-37°F) and daylight hours significantly reduced to 6-7 hours by month's end. November has the highest relative humidity in Turku, around 88%. This is low season for tourism, though the city maintains a vibrant local atmosphere with cultural events and cozy indoor activities. The Student Union of the University of Turku celebrates its anniversary in November with gala events and traditions. The first snow of the season often falls in November, transforming the city. Traditional winter foods appear on restaurant menus, including hearty stews and seasonal game dishes. Christmas markets begin to open in late November, with decorations and lights being installed throughout the city. This is a good time to experience Turku like a local, with fewer tourists and authentic cultural experiences.

Early December brings winter conditions with temperatures around freezing and very short daylight hours (around 6 hours). Christmas markets appear throughout the city, particularly at the Old Great Square, offering traditional crafts, decorations, and seasonal foods like glögi (mulled wine) and piparkakku (gingerbread cookies). Shopping streets and squares are beautifully decorated with lights, creating a magical atmosphere despite the darkness.

Finland's Independence Day is celebrated on December 6th, commemorating independence from Russia in 1917. Official ceremonies include raising the flag, a religious service at Turku Cathedral, and various commemorative events throughout the city. Many Turku residents place two blue and white candles in their windows as a symbol of independence.

Mid-December continues with winter festivities and holiday preparations. Christmas markets are in full swing, and indoor cultural events provide respite from the cold weather. The darkest time of the year is approaching, with only 5-6 hours of daylight. St. Lucia Day on December 13th brings processions of light to churches and public spaces. The week before Christmas sees Turku at its most festive, with decorations, lights, and special events throughout the city. Turku's title as the 'Christmas City of Finland' is evident with its festive atmosphere.

One of Finland's oldest traditions and most important Christmas events, the Declaration of Christmas Peace, has been read in Turku's Old Great Square since the 1320s. At noon on Christmas Eve, thousands gather to hear the declaration read from the balcony of Brinkkala Mansion, officially beginning the Christmas holiday. This ceremony is broadcast nationally and represents the true start of Christmas for many Finns.

Christmas is celebrated primarily on Christmas Eve (December 24) in Finland, with family gatherings for traditional Christmas dinner featuring dishes like ham, various casseroles, and rice porridge. Many restaurants and attractions close early on Christmas Eve and may remain closed on Christmas Day and Boxing Day (December 26). Public transportation runs on limited schedules. Despite this, winter tourism begins to increase as international visitors arrive for holiday celebrations.

The period between Christmas and New Year sees Turku quiet but festive. Winter activities like cross-country skiing and ice skating at outdoor rinks are popular, and museums welcome visitors seeking indoor activities during the cold weather. Many restaurants and shops reopen after brief Christmas closures. This can be a good time to visit for those seeking a quieter experience of the city while still enjoying the holiday atmosphere.

New Year's Eve celebrations center around the Old Great Square and the Aura River with a countdown and fireworks at midnight visible across the city. Many restaurants offer special New Year's Eve menus (advance reservation essential), while hotels and cultural venues host celebration events. The city maintains a festive atmosphere with locals and tourists gathering to welcome the New Year.
